There were two decisions from the US Supreme Court today on racial bias in jury selection.
Both decisions rebuke lower courts for not being vigilant enough in making sure the process is free of discrimination.
NPR's legal affairs correspondent Nina Totenberg reports.
The case of Thomas Miller-El, an African-American convicted of murder 19 years ago, has been to the Supreme Court twice.

The first time, two years ago, the court sent the case back to the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals with orders to rethink its, quote, ""dismissive and strained interpretation"" of the proof of discrimination Miller-El's lawyers had offered.
The court noted that prosecutors used their peremptory challenges--that is challenges for no stated reason--to strike 10 of 11 eligible black jurors.
As a red-faced Justice Anthony Kennedy put it...
Happenstance is unlikely to produce this disparity.

Moreover, as the court noted, prosecutors had questioned black jurors more aggressively than white, struck black jurors who gave substantially the same answers as white jurors who were seated and prosecutors had twice used a local procedure known as `the jury shuffle' to move blacks lower down on the list of potential jurors.
There were other factors, too, like the training manual for the Dallas DA's office instructing prosecutors not to seat minorities because they would be more sympathetic to the defense.
The vote in the 2002 Miller-El case was 8-to-1, with Justice Clarence Thomas dissenting.

But when it went back to the 5th Circuit for further review, that court ruled that there had been no race discrimination and, amazingly, it adopted almost verbatim the language of Thomas' dissent, not the court majority.
Today, the Supreme Court kicked back pretty hard, reversing Miller-El's conviction and declaring that the 5th Circuit's conclusion was `insupportable.
A six-justice majority said there is clear and convincing proof that the jury selection was tainted by racial bias.

As for the prosecutors' explanations, the court said, they were a sham and a pretext as exemplified by the fact that 100 percent of the blacks were subjected to a trick question that would disqualify them while only 27 percent of the whites were.
Writing for the three dissenters, Justice Clarence Thomas said the majority was merely speculating that there had been discrimination.
`On the merits of the facts and the law rather than sentiments,' he said, `Miller-El does not merit a new trial.'
In Texas, neither the Dallas DA's office nor the state attorney general's office would comment on today's ruling or say whether they would retry Miller-El.
But it was hard to see today's decision as anything but a rebuke to both the prosecutor's office and the 5th Circuit.
Eric Holder served as US attorney and deputy attorney general in the Clinton administration.
They really need to ask some very, very probing questions of themselves and wonder why a Supreme Court could make the specific findings that it made today that are so damning.

And I don't know if it's stubbornness by the 5th Circuit, but I think the Supreme Court has made it clear that they expect more rigorous review by the 5th Circuit and every other circuit in the United States of these death penalty appeals.
The Miller-El case comes from Texas, with the second-largest number of people on death row.
